title: Biggin Dale Walking Route

images.title: Martin Wilson / End of Biggin Dale
images.caption: End of Biggin Dale. What appears to be a path in the foreground is a stream, running to meet the River Dove flowing down Wolfscote Dale.

images.title: Nikki Mahadevan / At the head of Biggin Dale
images.caption: At the head of Biggin Dale. The dale as approached from Dale Head via a bridle path. This limestone valley is a National Nature Reserve managed by the National Trust.

images.title: Alan Heardman / Biggin Dale View
images.caption: Footpaths join near to the wood, to the right is the path to Dalehead and to the left is the path to Hartington. The slope under the trees seems to be a popular place for walkers to stop for a break.

images.title: Nikki Mahadevan / Dew pond in Biggin Dale
images.caption: This dew pond can be found at a junction in the footpath through Biggin Dale. Looking towards the footpath that continues to Dale Head from the footpath that leads to Dale End.

images.title: Nigel Judd / Wolfescote Dale from Biggin Dale
images.caption: Wolfescote Dale viewed from Biggin Dale

images.title: Dew pond in Biggin Dale by John Sutton, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Dew pond

images.title: Alan Heardman / Old Barn
images.caption: Old Barn on the footpath between Biggin Dale and Reynards Lane

images.title: Paul Glover / Dale End
images.caption: Dale End. At the start of the path into Biggin Dale.

description: This walk explores the beautiful Biggin Dale National Nature Reserve in the Peak District. You can start the walk from the little village of Biggin, just to the east of the reserve. The Waterloo Inn is a good start an end point to the walk. From here follow public footpaths south to Dalhead before turning west to reach the reserve. A footpath then heads south through the site, passing the caves before reaching  the River Dove at Wolfscote Dale. You can extend the walk by continuing along the delightful riverside paths either to the south or north west. As a nature reserve there's lots of different plants and wildflowers to see in the warmer months. The limestone scenery encourages pretty flowers such as purple orchid, harebells and bluebells in the spring.
